    • Field Detail

      • dumbAISelf

        private NaiveAI dumbAISelf
        The naive AI is used to check if either the opponent or this AI himself can win in just one move.

      • dumbAIOpponent

        private NaiveAI dumbAIOpponent
        The naive AI is used to check if either the opponent or this AI himself can win in just one move.

      • prudence

        private double prudence
        Sets the priority of this AI. A value of 0.0 means the AI will only go for his own win, without blocking the opponent. Not including situations where the opponent can win in the next move. A value of 1.0 means the AI is full defensive and will only try to block the opponent. Except for instant-win opportunities.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Yuno

        public Yuno(java.lang.String username,
            Chip chip,
            double prudence)
        Create the Yuno computer player, which is smarter than the Naive AI. Yuno looks for the move that will result in the most potential. Potential is defined in the FieldSlice class.
        Parameters:
        username - the username of this (computer) player, that will be sent to the server
        chip - the chip of this (computer) player
        prudence - sets the priority of this AI. A value of 0.0 means the AI will only go for his own win, without blocking the opponent. Not including situations where the opponent can win in the next move. A value of 1.0 means the AI is full defensive and will only try to block the opponent. Except for instant-win opportunities.

    • Method Detail

      • getMove

        public java.awt.Point getMove(Field field)
        Description copied from class: ComputerPlayer
        . Starts the thinking process of the ComputerPlayer and returns the move the AI has determined on.
        Specified by:
        getMove in class ComputerPlayer
        Parameters:
        field - is a copy of the current playing field used by the ComputerPlayer to determine the next move.
        Returns:
        the move in the form of a java.awt.Point

      • bestMove

        private java.awt.Point bestMove(Field field,
                                double[][] potentials,
                                double[][] dangers,
                                java.util.ArrayList<java.awt.Point> illegals)
        Calculate the best moves in terms of the net potential. Which is the difference between the potential and danger (potential of the opponent). The prudence factor sets the weight of the potential and the danger in the calculation of the netto potential.
        Parameters:
        field - a copy of the current playing field
        potentials - the potential for the computer player self
        dangers - the potential of the opponent
        illegals - the moves that should be discarded, because they are either illegal (the column is full) or they result in an instant win for the opponent.
        Returns:
        a java.awt.Point representing the best move in terms of net potential.

      • calculateMovePotentials

        private double[][] calculateMovePotentials(Field field,
                                           Chip c)
        Calculate the potential of all possible moves for a certain colour Chip.
        Parameters:
        field - a copy of the current playing field
        c - the chip for which the potential is to be calculated
        Returns:
        an 2-dim array in which the potential for every possible move is stored.

      • totalPotential

        private double totalPotential(Field field,
                              Chip c)
        Calculate the potential of a certain field.
        Parameters:
        field - the field for which the potential is to be calculated
        c - the chip for which the potential is to be calculated
        Returns:
        the potential of the given field

      • sliceField

        private FieldSlice sliceField(Field field,
                              int startX,
                              int startY,
                              int dx,
                              int dy)
        Slice a 2D field out of the actual 3D field.
        Parameters:
        field - a copy of the 3D field
        startX - the starting x-coordinate where the slice starts
        startY - the starting y-coordinate where the slice starts
        dx - the x-direction of the slice vector
        dy - the y-direction of the slice vector
        Returns:
        a FieldSlice object representing the 2D slice
